Tymoshenko herself was not present in the courtroom because of her health condition.{{cite web|url=http://www.radiosvoboda.mobi/a/24408285.html|title=The court considered possible a preliminary review of the complaint Tymoshenko without her|publisher= Radio Svoboda|date=1 December 2011|accessdate=1 December 2011}} After the hearing, the judge, Olena Sitaylo, had to call an ambulance and was hospitalized. On 13 December 2011, the Kyiv Court of Appeal resumed the hearing. All subsequent court sessions took place without Tymoshenko's presence. Immediately prior to the hearing of the appeal, the board of judges was altered: Sitaylo, the chief justice, was appointed the day before the first hearing; other justices were appointed several days prior to the court session.{{cite web|url=http://novaukraina.org/news/urn:news:AA7F7D|title=The trial of Tymoshenko will continue "in any weather"|publisher= Novaukraina.org|date=20 December 2011|accessdate=20 December 2011}} Thus, the judges did not have time to study the 84-page case log. The manner of the process proved that the decision to alter the board of judges was made beforehand. At the very end, Tymoshenko's defense boycotted the court session.{{cite web|url=http://fakty.ictv.ua/ua/index/read-news/id/1437911|title=Protection of Tymoshenko will not go to court|publisher= Fakty.ictv.ua|date=22 December 2011|accessdate=22 December 2011}} On 23 December 2011, the Kyiv Court of Appeal issued a ruling which fully supported the verdict of the Pechersk court. The judges didn't find any violations during the pre-trial investigation or trial on the "gas case", overruling the claims of Tymoshenko's defense.{{cite web|url=http://en.for-ua.com/news/2011/12/14/125211.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120709040426/http://en.for-ua.com/news/2011/12/14/125211.html|archivedate=9 July 2012 |title=Court of Appeals leaves Yulia Tymoshenko in custody |publisher=En.for-ua.com |date=14 December 2011 |accessdate=28 December 2013}} ====Cassation==== On 26 January 2012, Tymoshenko's defense submitted a [[Court of cassation|cassation appeal]] to the High Specialized Court for Civil and Criminal Cases regarding the "gas case" verdict.{{cite web|url=http://en.for-ua.com/news/2012/01/26/144035.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120709112624/http://en.for-ua.com/news/2012/01/26/144035.html|archivedate=9 July 2012 |title=Tymoshenko's defense submitted cassation appeal against "gas sentence" |publisher=En.for-ua.com |date=26 January 2012 |accessdate=28 December 2013}} On 16 August 2012, after a 7-month delay that impeded filing the case to the European Court of Human Rights, the panel of judges of the aforementioned court began hearing the case. The panel finished hearing the case on 21 August and went to the jury room to make decision. The ruling of the Court, issued on 29 August 2012, stated that the appeal of former Prime Minister Yulia Tymoshenko's defense on the "gas case" should not be satisfied.{{cite web|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/content/politics/court-reads-out-cassation-complaints-against-tymoshenkos-gas-case-verdict-311681.html |title=Tymoshenko's cassation in gas case read out in court |publisher=Kyivpost.com |date=17 August 2012 |accessdate=28 December 2013}} Media, diplomats, members of parliament and members of an EU special monitoring mission, Pat Cox and Aleksander Kwaśniewski, attended the court sessions. The ruling was announced on the day following public hearing of "Tymoshenko vs Ukraine" (regarding unlawful arrest of ex-prime minister and holding her in custody) case at the European Court of Human Rights.{{cite web|url=http://www.rbc.ua/ukr/analytics/espch-nachal-publichnye-slushaniya-po-delu-timoshenko-protiv-28082012143100|title=The European Court of human rights has completed its public hearings in the case "Tymoshenko against Ukraine"|publisher= Rbc.ua|date=28 August 2012|accessdate=28 August 2012}} The European Union, PACE, and governments of the United States, Great Britain and Canada expressed frustration with the cassation ruling.{{cite web|url=http://www.day.kiev.ua/en/article/day-after-day/staunch-court |title=A staunch court |publisher=Day.kiev.ua |date=4 September 2012 |accessdate=28 December 2013}} "We are deeply disappointed with the consequences of the current situation, when two important opposition leaders cannot stand in the upcoming parliamentary elections, [and] when the court disrespects international standards for fair and transparent processes", a representative of the European Commission, Michael Mann, said in Brussels on 29 August 2012.{{cite web|url=http://old.nrcu.gov.ua/en/148/509412/|title=EU deeply disappointed by court ruling on Tymoshenko's appeal against gas case verdict|publisher= Old.nrcu.gov.ua |date=29 August 2012|accessdate=29 August 2012}} ====International reactions==== [[File:Yulia and Yevhenia Tymoshenko.jpg|thumb|[[Eugenia Tymoshenko]] at the podium in 2011.]] The "gas case" trial was viewed by many European and American organizations as a politically charged persecution that violates the law.{{cite web|format=PDF |url= http://helsinki.org.ua/files/docs/1321265218.pdf |title=Legal Monitoring in Ukraine III: Preliminary Report on the investigations against Yulia Tymoshenko in November 2011 |work=The Danish Helsinki Committee for Human Rights|date=8 November 2011 |accessdate=7 November 2015}}{{cite web |author=Pieter Omtzigt |format=PDF|url=http://www.assembly.coe.int/Communication/ajdoc15_2013.pdf |title=Committee on Legal Affairs and Human Rights: Keeping political and criminal responsibility http://www.echr.coe.int/sites/search_eng/pages/search.aspx#{%22fulltext%22:[%22Tymoshenko%22]} |title=ECHR |publisher=Echr.coe.int |date= |accessdate=26 July 2014}}{{cite web|last=Spillius |first=Alex |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/ukraine/10324152/EU-to-Kiev-free-Yulia-Tymoshenko-or-no-pact.html |title=EU to Kiev: free Yulia Tymoshenko, or no pact |publisher=Telegraph |accessdate=28 December 2013}}{{cite news |url= http://news.liga.net/news/politics/676066-zakharov_zayavil_chto_timoshenko_bezuslovno_politzaklyuchennaya.htm |script-title=ru:Захаров заявил, что Тимошенко - безусловно политзаключенная |trans-title=Zakharov declared that Tymoshenko - is undoubtedly a political prisoner |language=ru |work=LIGA.net|date=7 June 2012 |accessdate=7 November 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://khpg.org/index.php?id=1313446474 |title=Danish Helsinki Committee: Legal Monitoring in Ukraine II, Full Text |publisher=Khpg.org |accessdate=28 December 2013}} The [[European Union]] and other international organizations see the conviction as "justice being applied selectively under political motivation."{{cite news |url= http://www.euronews.com/2011/10/11/eu-feels-let-down-by-ukraine-over-tymoshenko/ |title=EU feels let down by Ukraine over Tymoshenko |work=[[Euronews]]|date=11 October 2011 |accessdate=6 November 2015}} The European Union has shelved the [[EU-Ukraine relations#European Union Association Agreement|European Union Association Agreement]] and [[EU-Ukraine relations#Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Agreement (DCFTA)|Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Agreement]] with Ukraine over the issue.{{cite web|last=Spillius |first=Alex |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/ukraine/10324152/EU-to-Kiev-free-Yulia-Tymoshenko-or-no-pact.html |title=EU to Kiev: free Yulia Tymoshenko, or no pact |publisher=Telegraph |accessdate=28 December 2013}}{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/content/politics/eu-leaders-ratification-of-association-agreement-a-310272.html|title=EU leaders:Ratification of Association Agreement and DCFTA depends on settlement of Tymoshenko-Lutsenko issue|publisher=Kyiv Post|agency=Interfax-Ukraine|date=20 July 2012}} The EU has repeatedly called for release of Tymoshenko as a primary condition for signing the EU Association Agreement.{{#tag:ref|European politicians deemed the court's decision to be politically motivated and a violation of democratic standards. The head of EU diplomacy, Catherine Ashton, said in a statement that the verdict would affect bilateral EU-Ukraine relations, including the Association Agreement. Commissioner for Enlargement Stefan Fule indicated that he was counting on Tymoshenko's rapid release through changes to Ukraine's Criminal Code. The head of the European People's Party, Wilfried Martens, has called for talks with Ukraine on the Association Agreement to be suspended. These responses correspond to the Union's current position; for the Association Agreement to be signed, Tymoshenko must be released and permitted to participate in the next elections.|group=nb}}{{cite web|author=Yulia Tymoshenko sentenced |url=http://www.osw.waw.pl/en/publikacje/analyses/2011-10-12/yulia-tymoshenko-sentenced |title=Yulia Tymoshenko sentenced |publisher=OSW |date=12 October 2011 |accessdate=28 December 2013}} In June 2012, the European Parliament established a special monitoring mission to Ukraine, conducted by former European Parliament President Pat Cox and former Polish President Aleksander Kwaśniewski. Both politicians have observed trials, repeatedly visited Tymoshenko in custody and conducted meetings with Ukraine's authorities regarding her release.{{cite web|url=http://ipress.ua/news/koks_i_kvasnievskyy_pryihaly_do_tymoshenko_v_likarnyu_21755.html|title=The mission of the European Parliament under the slogan "Julia will" have arrived to Timoshenko|publisher= Ipress.ua|date=15 June 2013|accessdate=15 June 2013}} The European Union shelved the [[EU-Ukraine relations#European Union Association Agreement|European Union Association Agreement]] and [[EU-Ukraine relations#Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Agreement (DCFTA)|Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Agreement]] with Ukraine over the issue. On 30 April 2013, the [[European Court of Human Rights]] issued a judgment{{cite web|url=http://hudoc.echr.coe.int/sites/fra-press/pages/search.aspx?i=003-4343134-5208270 |title=HUDOC Search Page |publisher=Hudoc.echr.coe.int |accessdate=28 December 2013}} asserting that "Ms. Tymoshenko's pre-trial detention had been arbitrary; that the lawfulness of her detention had not been properly reviewed; and, that she had no possibility to seek compensation for her unlawful deprivation of liberty." [[Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe]] (PACE) has adopting a resolution on "Keeping political and criminal responsibility separate" in which former Prime Minister of Ukraine Yulia Tymoshenko is recognized as a political prisoner.{{cite web|url=http://www.tymoshenko.ua/en/article/yulia_tymoshenko_02_07_2013_01|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130709095208/http://www.tymoshenko.ua/en/article/yulia_tymoshenko_02_07_2013_01|archivedate=9 July 2013 |title=PACE: Yulia Tymoshenko is a political prisoner|publisher=tymoshenko.ua |accessdate=2 July 2013}} The United States Senate passed two resolutions calling for the release from prison of former prime minister Tymoshenko. The most recent, presented in the Senate in June 2013, called for Tymoshenko's release in light of the recent European Court of Human Rights ruling, and was adopted on 18 November 2013.{{cite web|url=https://www.congress.gov/bill/113th-congress/senate-resolution/165/text |title=United States Senate Resolution on Ukraine. Full Text |publisher=Beta.congress.gov |accessdate=28 December 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://un.ua/eng/article/477245.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131119102528/http://un.ua/eng/article/477245.html|archivedate=19 November 2013 |title=U.S. Senate Adopts Resolution Demanding Ukraine Release Tymoshenko Under European Court of Human Rights' Ruling on Her Illegal Detention And Arrest |publisher=Un.ua |date=20 November 2013 |accessdate=28 December |url=https://www.opencongress.org/bill/sres466-112/show |title=US Congress Resolution 466 |publisher=Opencongress.org |accessdate=28 December 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131031020123/http://www.opencongress.org/bill/sres466-112/show |archivedate=31 October 2013 |df=dmy-all }} On 2 October 2013, the [[Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe]] (PACE) adopted a resolution calling for the immediate release of Tymoshenko and, two days later, [[Pat Cox]] and [[Aleksander Kwaśniewski]], representatives of the [[European Parliament]] mission, handed president Yanukovych a petition to pardon Tymoshenko.{{cite web|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/content/politics/pace-calls-for-tymoshenko-release-330035.html |title=PACE calls for Tymoshenko release |publisher=Kyivpost.com |date=2 October 2013 |accessdate=28 December 2013}} {{cite web |author= |url= http://www.ukrinform.net/rubric-politics/1556262-cox_kwasniewski_asking_yanukovych_to_pardon_tymoshenko_310607.html |title=Cox, Kwasniewski asking Yanukovych to pardon Tymoshenko |publisher=Ukrinform.ua |date=4 October 2013 |accessdate=28 December 2013 }} On 21 February 2014, Parliament voted to allow the release of former Prime Minister Yulia Tymoshenko, who has been imprisoned for more than two years. In December 2012, the united opposition nominated her and later in June 2013 confirmed her as its candidate in the [[2015 Ukrainian presidential election]].[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/157239.html Batkivschyna to nominate Tymoshenko for presidency, Yatseniuk heads party's political council], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (14 June 2013) ==== Aftermath — Manafort case ==== According to the September 2018 indictment in which [[Paul Manafort]] confessed as part of a plea bargain with [[U.S.]] [[special prosecutor]] [[Robert Mueller]], Manafort helped former Ukrainian President [[Viktor Yanukovych]] to conduct a media campaign in the West directed against Tymoshenko in order to undermine the support for her by [[Presidency of Barack Obama|the administration]] of then U.S. President [[Barack Obama]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/apr/05/ex-trump-aide-paul-manafort-approved-black-ops-to-help-ukraine-president|title=Ex-Trump aide Paul Manafort approved 'black ops' to help Ukraine president|last=Harding|first=Luke|date=5 April 2018|work=The Guardian|access-date=6 April 2018|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}} The campaign was designed to make Tymoshenko look like a supporter of [[anti-Semitism]].[https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/manafort-s-mysterious-israeli-connection-everything-we-know-so-far-1.6489514 Manafort’s Mysterious Israeli Connection: Everything We Know So Far], [[Haaretz]] (18 September 2018) The indictment also states that in July 2011, former U.S. journalist [[Alan Friedman]] sent Manafort a confidential six-page document entitled "Ukraine - the digital road map", which contained a plan for "destruction" of Tymoshenko using video, articles and social networks.[https://m.huffpost.com/us/entry/us_5b9c2e61e4b046313fbb2867 Paul Manafort’s Plea Deal Could Be Bad News For A Bunch Of Washington Operatives], [[Huffpost]] (14 September 2018) The plan included creating a website, posting on the Internet, and sending out e-mails to "the target audience in Europe and the U.S." It was also proposed to edit the page of Yulia Tymoshenko in Wikipedia in order to emphasize the "corruption and legal proceedings" related to her. ===2014 release from prison=== [[File:Yulia Tymoshenko addressing Euromaidan with a speech. Kyiv, Ukraine. Events of February 22, 2014..jpg|thumb|left|Tymoshenko addressing [[Euromaidan]] with a speech, Kiev, 22 February 2014]] Following the [[2014 Ukrainian Revolution]], on 21 February 2014, Parliament voted for her release in a 310–54 veto-proof vote. To do so, the members of parliament decriminalized the Article on which Tymoshenko was charged and brought it into compliance with Article 19 of the UN Convention against corruption. That could enable immediate release of Tymoshenko through the corresponding court ruling. However, Viktor Yanukovych fled the country after massive [[2014 Ukrainian revolution|violent clashes in Kiev that killed more than 80 people]]{{cite news|author1=Maria Danilova|author2=Yuras Karmanau|url=http://www.ctvnews.ca/world/tensions-high-at-kyiv-protest-camp-despite-ground-breaking-deal-1.1697154|title=Tensions high at Kyiv protest camp despite ground-breaking deal|agency=[[CTV News]]|date=21 February 2014|accessdate=6 November 2015}} without signing the bill into law. On 22 February 2014, the Verkhovna Rada with 322 votes adopted a decree based on the decision of the European Court of Human Rights and corresponding decision of the Committee of Ministers of the Council of Europe.{{cite news |url= http://www.voanews.com/content/ukraines-tymoshenko-declares-presidential-candidacy/1880823.html |title=Ukraine's Tymoshenko Declares Presidential Candidacy |publisher=[[Voice of America]] |date=27 March 2014 |accessdate=6 November 2015}}{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-26312008 |title=Ukraine: Speaker Oleksandr Turchynov named interim president |agency= [[BBC News]] |date=23 February 2014 |accessdate=6 November 2015}}
{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-26248275 |title=Ukraine protests timeline |agency=[[BBC News]] |date=23 February 2014 |accessdate=6 November 2015}}{{cite news|url=https://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/coe-committee-of-ministers-urges-ukrainian-government-to-compensate-tymoshenko-for-violated-rights-333190.html|title=Council of Europe Committee of Ministers urges Ukrainian government to compensate Tymoshenko for violated rights|publisher=Kyivpost.com|agency=Interfax-Ukraine|date=6 December 2013|accessdate=6 November 2015}} On the same day, Tymoshenko was released from Central Clinical Hospital No. 5 in [[Kharkiv]], where she had been receiving treatment under police guard since May 2012, after being diagnosed with a [[spinal disc herniation]].{{cite news|author=Shaun Walker|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/feb/23/yulia-tymoshenko-returns-ukraine-politics|title=Yulia Tymoshenko is back centre stage in Ukraine – but not all want her there|publisher=The Guardian|date=24 February 2014|location=Kiev|accessdate=6 November 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/content/politics/opposition-leaders-visit-tymoshenkos-hospital-316059.html|title=Opposition leaders visit Tymoshenko's hospital|publisher=[[Kyiv Post]]|date=13 November 2012|location=Kharkiv|accessdate=24 February 2014}}
{{Citation |url=http://www.kyivpost.com/content/politics/german-doctors-arrive-at-kharkiv-based-clinic-to-see-tymoshenko-316141.html |title=German doctors arrive at Kharkiv-based clinic to see Tymoshenko |journal=[[Kyiv Post]] |location=Kharkiv |date=15 November 2012}}
{{Citation |url=http://www.kyivpost.com/content/world/rome-mayors-office-puts-up-tymoshenko-portrait-on-facade-316747.html |title=Rome mayor's office puts up Tymoshenko portrait on facade |newspaper=[[Kyiv Post]] |date=26 November 2012}}
{{Citation |url=http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/191607.html |title=Ukraine opposition leader demands closure of protesters' cases, Tymoshenko release |newspaper=[[Interfax-Ukraine]] |date=21 February 2014 |accessdate=24 February 2014}}{{Citation |url=http://rapsinews.com/judicial_news/20120831/264475915.html |title=France disappointed by Tymoshenko appeal rejection |newspaper=rapsinews.com |date=31 August 2012 |location=Paris}} Her release was praised by western leaders.{{cite web|url=http://www.tymoshenko.ua/en/article/yulia_tymoshenko_23_02_2014_06|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140307071749/http://www.tymoshenko.ua/en/article/yulia_tymoshenko_23_02_2014_06|archivedate=7 March 2014 |title=Yulia Tymoshenko meets with EU and U.S. diplomats (photos) – Yulia Tymoshenko. Official Website |publisher=Tymoshenko.ua |date= |accessdate=26 July 2014}} On 28 February 2014, the parliament rehabilitated Yulia Tymoshenko and restored her rights.{{cite web |url= http://sputniknews.com/voiceofrussia/news/2014_03_03/Ukraines-ex-Prime-Minister-Yulia-Tymoshenko-officially-rehabilitated-3865/ |title=Ukraine's ex-Prime Minister Yulia Tymoshenko officially rehabilitated |publisher=The Voice of Russia |date=3 March 2014 |accessdate=26 July 2014}}{{cite news |title=Embattled Ukraine President Signs Compromise Deal as Parliament Votes to Free His Imprisoned Rival |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2014/02/22/world/europe/ukraine.html?emc=edit_na_20140221&_r=0 |accessdate=21 February 2014 |newspaper=New York Times |date=21 February 2014 |author=Andrew Higgins |author2=Andrew Cramer |registration=yes}}{{cite web |url= http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/ukraine-crisis/ally-opposition-icon-tymoshenko-voted-acting-ukraine-president-n36531 |title=Ally of Opposition Icon Tymoshenko Voted Acting Ukraine President |publisher=NBC News |date=23 February 2014 |accessdate=25 February 2014}} That enabled her to run for office; however, she has ruled out becoming prime minister again.{{cite news|url=http://www.malaysiasun.com/index.php/sid/220190358|title=President Yanukovych and Ukraine opposition sign early poll deal|publisher=[[The Sun (Malaysia)]]|date=21 February 2014|location=Kiev|accessdate=24 February 2014}} Kyivsky District Court of Kharkiv closed the criminal case on financial abuse of the [[United Energy Systems of Ukraine]] on 28 February 2014.[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/193370.html Kharkiv court drops charges against Tymoshenko in UESU case], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (28 February 2014) And, on 14 April, the [[Supreme Court of Ukraine]] closed the "[[Yulia Tymoshenko#2011 trial and imprisonment and other criminal cases against Tymoshenko|gas case]]" against Tymoshenko for "absence of a criminal act".{{cite news|url=http://tass.ru/en/world/729631|title=Ukrainian Prosecutor General's Office opens case vs. judges who sentenced Tymoshenko|publisher=[[ITAR-TASS]]|date=25 April 2014|accessdate=6 November 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://tass.ru/en/world/727757|title=Ukrainian Supreme Court closes Tymoshenko's 'gas case'|publisher=[[ITAR-TASS]]|date=14 April 2014|accessdate=6 November 2015}} On 25 April 2014, the [[General Prosecutor of Ukraine]] launched a pre-trial investigation against a number of officials from its own office and the Pechersky district court and Kiev's court of appeals (the judges who had sentenced Tymoshenko) because of allegedly "deliberate, systematic and flagrant violation of accused Yulia Tymoshenko's rights to defense, which are granted by Ukraine's current laws". On 24 June 2014, the [[Supreme Court of Ukraine]] rehabilitated Tymoshenko.[http://vestnikkavkaza.net/news/politics/56829.html Ukrainian Supreme Court rehabilitates Julia Tymoshenko]''vestnikkavkaza.net''(24 June 2014){{cite news |url= http://tass.ru/en/world/727757 |title=Ukrainian Supreme Court closes Tymoshenko's 'gas case' |work=ITAR-TASS |date=14 April 2014 |accessdate=26 July 2014}}{{cite web |url= http://www.humanrightseurope.org/2015/01/ukraine-court-discontinues-examination-of-tymoshenko-human-rights-complaint/ |title=Ukraine: Court "discontinues" examination of Tymoshenko human rights complaint |publisher=humanrightseurope.org|date= |accessdate=22 January 2015}}{{cite web |url= http://www.dw.com/en/echr-tymoshenko-suit-over-ukraine-treatment-settled/a-18208499 |title=ECHR:Tymoshenko suit over Ukraine treatment settled |publisher=dw.com|date=22 January 2015 |accessdate=6 November 2015}} On 22 January 2015, the [[European Court of Human Rights]] announced the termination of consideration of the case of ''Yulia Tymoshenko v. Ukraine'' in connection to an implied friendly settlement between the parties, after Tymoshenko's agreement with the government's declaration admitting that the criminal prosecution against her had been politically motivated. The Ukrainian government, in its exchange with the Court, had acknowledged a violation of Tymoshenko's rights guaranteed by the European Convention on Human Rights under articles 3 (prohibition of torture), 6 (right to a fair trial), 7 (no punishment without law), 8 (right to respect for private and family life), partly in conjunction with article 13 (right to an effective remedy), article 18 (political motivation), article 10 (freedom of expression) and article 4 of Protocol No. 7 to the Convention (right not to be tried or punished twice). Taking note of the Ukrainian government's declaration and following measures, as well as of Tymoshenko's agreement with it, the Court struck out the application from its list of cases, as asked by the government, following article 39 of the Convention (friendly settlements).[http://hudoc.echr.coe.int/app/conversion/pdf/?library=ECHR&id=003-4988882-6120225&filename=Decision%20Tymoshenko%20v.%20Ukraine%20%28no.%202%29%20-%20examination%20discontinued.pdf European Court discontinues examination of second case brought by former Ukrainian Prime Minister Tymoshenko], ECHR Press Release, 22 January 2015 On 19 October 2015, the Kominternivskyi district court of Kharkiv has sentenced two former employees of the Kachanivska penal colony No. 54 to three years in prison for inflicting injuries on Tymoshenko.[http://en.censor.net.ua/news/356901/tymoshenkos_jailers_sentenced_to_three_years_in_prison/Tymoshenko's jailers sentenced to three years in prison]{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, en.censor.net.ua (20 October 2015) ===Political activities after release=== Immediately after her release from prison on 22 February 2014, Yulia Tymoshenko travelled to Kyiv, where she attended a makeshift memorial to the first slain protesters on Hrushevskogo Street and gave a speech on Maidan stage.{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/ukraine/10656391/Freed-Yulia-Tymoshenko-praises-heroes-and-liberators.html |title=Video: Freed Yulia Tymoshenko praises 'heroes and liberators' |publisher=Telegraph |date=23 February 2014 |accessdate=26 July 2014}} In the following days, she had a number of meetings and phone conversations with USA, EU, and OSCE officials. Tymoshenko addressed the European Union, leaders of western democracies and of countries which guaranteed Ukraine's territorial unity according to the Budapest Memorandum; she called for action to stop what she called the "Russian aggression".{{cite web|author=MARIA DANILOVA |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/03/05/tymoshenko-west-must-stop-russia_n_4906708.html |title=Tymoshenko: West Must Stop Russia's Aggression |publisher=Huffingtonpost.com |date= |accessdate=26 July 2014}} From 6 to 7 March, Tymoshenko attended a political conference of the [[European People's Party]] in Dublin, where she openly discussed events with [[Angela Merkel]], [[Jose Manuel Barroso]], [[Viviane Reding]], [[Michel Barnier]], [[Mariano Rajoy]] and [[Donald Tusk]], amongst other notable figures.{{cite news|author=Suzanne Lynch|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/news/politics/tymoshenko-among-kiev-uprising-figures-to-visit-dublin-1.1712132|title=Tymoshenko among Kiev uprising figures to visit Dublin|work=The Irish Times|date=4 March 2014|accessdate=7 November 2015}} On 7 March 2014, she was admitted to the Charité hospital in Berlin, Germany, for treatment of her severe back problems.{{cite news|url=http://www.morgenpost.de/berlin-aktuell/article125568742/Timoschenko-in-Berlin-Charite-Aerzte-bereiten-Behandlung-vor.html|title=Timoschenko in Berlin - Charité-Ärzte bereiten Behandlung vor|trans-title= Tymoshenko in Berlin - Charité-Ärzte doctors prepare for treatment|language=de|work=Berliner Morgenpost|date=7 March 2014|accessdate=7 November 2015}} Upon her return to Kyiv, Tymoshenko gathered military and defense experts and suggested launching a special headquarters that would elaborate responses to threats coming from Russia. [[File:Tymoshenko 2014(PR).png|thumb|250px|2014 presidential election percentage of vote for Tymoshenko]] On 27 March 2014, at a press conference in Kiev, Tymoshenko stated that she would run in the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2014|2014 presidential election]].{{cite news|author1=Patrick Reevell|author2=David M. Herszenhorn|author3=Steven Erlanger|author-link3=Steven Erlanger|author4=Rick Gladstone|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/03/28/world/europe/ukraine.html?_r=1|title=Former Prime Minister Announces Candidacy for President of Ukraine|publisher=The New York Times|date=27 March 2014|accessdate=7 November 2015}} Two days later, the congress of Batkivshchyna party officially nominated her and on 31 March the Central Election Commission officially registered her as a candidate. The election took place on 25 May. Tymoshenko came a distant second behind [[Petro Poroshenko]]. She received 12.39% of the vote.{{cite web|url= http://www.nrcu.gov.ua/en/148/566632/ |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20140529212731/http://nrcu.gov.ua/en/148/566632/ |archivedate=29 May 2014 |title=Poroshenko wins presidential election with 54.7% of vote – CEC |publisher=[[Radio Ukraine International]] |date=29 May 2014 }}{{cite news|author=David Stern|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-27569057|title=Petro Poroshenko claims Ukraine presidency|publisher=BBC News Online|date=25 May 2014|accessdate=26 May 2014}}{{cite news|url=http://www.pravdareport.com/world/ussr/26-05-2014/127649-chocolate_king_poroshenko-0/|title=Chocolate King Poroshenko beats Orange Princess Tymoshenko|publisher=[[Pravda.ru]]|date=26 May 2014|accessdate=6 November 2015}} In a recording (purportedly a leaked phone conversation with [[Nestor Shufrych]], former deputy secretary of the National Security and Defense Council of Ukraine) Tymoshenko appeared to say in reference to the reunification of [[Republic of Crimea|Crimea]] with Russia: "This is really beyond all boundaries. It's about time we grab our guns and go kill those damn Russians together with their leader; and nuke 8 million Russians who are now exiles in Ukraine."{{cite web|url=https://www.rt.com/news/tymoshenko-calls-destroy-russia-917/|title=Time to grab guns and kill damn Russians – Tymoshenko in leaked tape|publisher=Rt.com|date= |accessdate=26 July 2014}}{{cite news| url= http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/ukraines-ex-pm-tymoshenko-take-arms-kill-russians-1441651 |title= Ukraine's Ex-PM Tymoshenko: Take up Arms and Kill the Russians |last= Mezzofiore |first= Gianluca |date= 24 March 2014 |work=[[International Business Times]]}} In a statement, while admitting she had spoken to Shufrych on the telephone, Tymoshenko denied having advocated the use of nuclear bombs against ethnic Russians in Ukraine, and avowed that the recording had been deliberately edited to discredit her.{{cite web|url=http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/197607.html|title=Tymoshenko admits speaking to Shufrych, says her words about Russians were edited|publisher=En.interfax.com.ua|date=25 March 2014|accessdate=26 July 2014}} Neither Tymoshenko nor anybody else in Ukraine can use nuclear weapons against anybody, as [[Nuclear weapons and Ukraine|Ukraine no longer has any nuclear weapons]], having given up the third largest nuclear weapons stockpile in the world{{cite web|url=http://www.nti.org/country-profiles/ukraine/nuclear/|title=Ukraine – Country Profiles – NTI|accessdate=2 August 2014}} in exchange for ([[Budapest Memorandum on Security Assurances#Breach of the agreement|subsequently violated]]) [[Budapest Memorandum on Security Assurances|international guarantees of her security and territorial integrity]]. She also suggested a 10-year tax break for enterprises that would develop alternative energy sources in Ukraine. Tymoshenko is for the cancellation of [[Verkhovna Rada]] deputies' [[Ukrainian deputy|immunity from prosecution]].[https://web.archive.org/web/20100516055907/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/66135/ Tymoshenko denies seeking deputy immunity from prosecution], ''Kyiv Post'' (8 May 2010) For Ukraine, Tymoshenko prefers the [[proportional representation]] [[voting system]] with [[open list]]s.[https://web.archive.org/web/20121006002141/http://www.kyivpost.com/content/politics/tymoshenko-proportional-voting-system-is-the-best--67699.html Tymoshenko: Proportional voting system is the best for Ukraine], ''Kyiv Post'' (26 May 2010) Tymoshenko wants to reform the forming of state executive bodies,[http://www.unian.info/politics/279740-tymoshenko-proposes-to-change-staff-policy-in-country-cardinally.html Tymoshenko proposes to change staff policy in country cardinally], [[UNIAN]] (22 October 2009) and favours giving [[parliamentary opposition]] "real instruments of influence on the [[Government of Ukraine|authorities]]". She also wants [[Law of Ukraine#Criminal justice system|Ukrainian court system]] reforms[https://web.archive.org/web/20110713175902/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/50107/ Tymoshenko promises to establish 'dictatorship of law' if she wins at presidential elections], ''Kyiv Post'' (5 October 2009) and wants devolution of executive power to [[local authorities]].[https://web.archive.org/web/20110713175935/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/50097/ Tymoshenko speaks in support of decentralization of power], ''Kyiv Post'' (5 October 2009)[https://web.archive.org/web/20110713180052/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/50391/ Tymoshenko approves of Poroshenko as foreign minister], ''Kyiv Post'' (9 October 2009) Together with representatives of regional governments, Tymoshenko expanded a Law that aimed to empower local authorities. In the summer of 2009, she claimed she tried to bring together different political parties in order to amend the constitution and switch to a [[parliamentary form of government]]. In February 2011, Tymoshenko stated "Viktor Yanukovych's naked attempt to hijack the election that precipitated the [[Orange Revolution]] should have resulted in him being banned from running in future elections." In November 2009, Tymoshenko called Ukraine "an absolutely ungovernable country" due to the changes to the [[Constitution of Ukraine]] as a part of a political compromise between the acting authorities (former-President [[Kuchma]]) and opposition during the [[Orange Revolution]].[https://web.archive.org/web/20091130180555/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/53612 Tymoshenko calls Ukraine 'absolutely ungovernable'], ''Kyiv Post'' (26 November 2009) (Tymoshenko has characterised those reforms as "incomplete",{{cite book|title=The Report: Emerging Ukraine 2007|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ATsTI1GeTs8C&pg=PA20|accessdate=30 January 2016|year=2007|publisher=Oxford Business Group|isbn=978-1-902339-68-9|page=20}} and the [[Yulia Tymoshenko Bloc]] voted against them in December 2004).[http://www.taraskuzio.net/media18_files/46.pdf Ukraine's constitutional crisis drags on] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724092950/http://www.taraskuzio.net/media18_files/46.pdf |date=24 July 2011 }} by [[Taras Kuzio]], ''Kyiv Post'' (10 January 2007) In January 2010, Tymoshenko called for urgent amendments to the Constitution via the majority of the [[Verkhovna Rada]] after a survey or plebiscite is conducted.[https://web.archive.org/web/20100127161838/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/57605/ Tymoshenko: Constitution must be amended after survey conducted on form of government], ''Kyiv Post'' (20 January 2010) In April 2011, she still believed the constitution "didn't work".[http://www.unian.info/politics/484388-tymoshenko-idea-of-united-opposition-is-great-deception-by-yanukovych.html Tymoshenko: idea of united opposition is great deception by Yanukovych], [[UNIAN]] (15 April 2010) On 21 May 2016, Tymoshenko expressed hope that the EU will provide Ukraine a visa-free regime. Tymoshenko stressed that the Ukrainian state is there to protect the world all over Europe, continuing to fight the Russian aggression.[http://uapress.info/uk/news/show/131743 The Ukrainian people deserve to receive a visa-free regime – Tymoshenko], uapress.info (21 May 2016) ==Family and personal life== {{Main article|Family of Yulia Tymoshenko}} Yulia Tymoshenko's mother, Lyudmila Mykolayivna Telehina (born Nelepova), was born on 11 August 1937 in [[Dnipropetrovsk]]. Her father, Volodymyr Abramovych Hrihyan, was born on 3 December 1937, also in Dnipropetrovsk. His Soviet passport gave his nationality as Latvian. His mother was Maria Yosypivna Hrihyan, born in 1909. [[Ukrainian media]] have published speculation regarding the genealogy of Tymoshenko. Some of the hypotheses have no scientific evidence (for example, the hypothesis of the [[Armenian people|Armenian]] origin of the surname "Grigyan"); {{ru icon}} [http://regnum.ru/news/989417.html Between Ukraine, Armenia and Latvia: Yulia Tymoshenko hides its identity], [[REGNUM News Agency]] (20 April 2008) some of the hypotheses (concerning her Jewish roots) have been labelled as provocative,[https://web.archive.org/web/20100210024601/http://www.tau.ac.il/Anti-Semitism/asw2007/ukraine.html Ukraine 2007], [[Stephen Roth Institute]] (2007) {{uk icon}} [http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2005/09/2/3012934/ Tymoshenko is Ukraine-Latvian nationality, but he loves the Jews], ''Ukrayinska Pravda'' (2 September 2005)[http://www.haaretz.com/jewish/2.209/debate-rages-over-whether-ukraine-presidential-hopeful-is-jewish-1.6323 Debate rages over whether Ukraine presidential hopeful is Jewish], ''[[Haaretz]]'' (10 November 2009)[https://web.archive.org/web/20100208160009/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/58739/ Campaign gets dirty: Leaflets smear Tymoshenko as ‘Jew’], ''Kyiv Post'' (5 February 2010) or could be designed to create negative [[public relations|PR]],[http://www.pravda.com.ua/rus/articles/2008/10/16/4452863/ Michael Dubinyansky. "Information war, holy war"], ''Ukrayinska Pravda'' 16 October 2008[http://ru.tsn.ua/ukrayina/v-snyatine-ustanovyat-memorialnuyu-dosku-abramu-kapitelmanu-dedu-timoshenko.html In Sniatyn install a plaque Abram Kapitelmanu – grandfather Tymoshenko.], ru.tsn.ua, 2 September 2009. – Provocative initiative "Party of Regions" (the author is a former member of "the Yulia Tymoshenko Bloc" Zinovy Boychuk) – under the advocacy company of "Tymoshenko is Jewish woman". although her Minister of Communications had in 2005 described her origins as half-Jewish, half-Armenian.[http://korrespondent.net/ukraine/events/129586-rabinovich-prizyvaet-ne-spekulirovat-na-izbienii-studenta-evreya-v-kieve Рабинович призывает не спекулировать на избиении студента-еврея в Киеве] Корреспондент.net, 31 августа 2005 About her ethnicity, Yulia Tymoshenko herself has said: "On my father's side – everyone is Latvian for ten generations, and on my mother's side – everyone is Ukrainian for ten generations."{{cite web|url=http://farysei.narod.ru/makuha/book2.html |title=# b2_2 The reply of the Prime Minister of Ukraine Yulia Tymoshenko to blame the Minister of Transport "Chervonenko, Eugene Alfredovich", autumn 2005 |publisher=Farysei.narod.ru |accessdate=11 October 2011}} Tymoshenko's parents were both born in Ukraine and are, therefore, Ukrainian as defined by the [[Law on Citizenship of Ukraine]] and by the [[Ukrainian Constitution]].{{cite web|url=http://www.mfa.gov.ua/mfa/en/273.htm|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081113161029/http://www.mfa.gov.ua/mfa/en/273.htm|archivedate=13 November 2008|title=Citizenship|accessdate=18 April 2008|work=Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Ukraine}}{{cite web|url=http://www.mfa.gov.ua/mfa/en/publication/content/719.htm|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081204201403/http://www.mfa.gov.ua/mfa/en/publication/content/719.htm|archivedate=4 December 2008|title=Law on Citizenship of Ukraine|accessdate=18 April 2008|work=[[Verkhovna Rada|Verkhovna Rada of Ukraine]]|publisher=Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Ukraine}}[https://web.archive.org/web/20101218222442/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/opinion/op_ed/detail/62040 Gender bias, anti-Semitism contributed to Yanukovych's victory], ''Kyiv Post'' (18 March 2010) Tymoshenko has said that, like most Soviet citizens, she spoke only Russian in her childhood (although she studied the [[Ukrainian language]] and [[Ukrainian literature]] at school for 10 years, as did all schoolchildren in [[Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic|Soviet Ukraine]]). In January 2010, Tymoshenko stated that in Dnipropetrovsk she did not have to speak Ukrainian until she was 36 (i.e. before 1996).{{ru icon}} [http://ria.ru/politics/20100103/202779743.html Тимошенко сказала, что по-украински стала говорить с 36 лет], [[RIA Novosti]] (3 January 2010); Quote: "Я начала говорить на украинском, когда мне было где-то 36 лет, а до этого у меня мама и вся семья – мы все разговаривали на русском. У меня до сих пор мама обычно не разговаривает на украинском." ("I beginning to speak in Ukrainian when I was around 36. Before that, my mother and the rest of my family, we all conversed in Russian. My mother still usually doesn't talk in Ukrainian.") According to Tymoshenko, her [[braids]] are a family tradition. In 1979, Yulia married businessman [[Oleksandr Tymoshenko]]{{cite web|url= http://file.liga.net/person/320-uliya-timoshenko.html |title= Dossier: Yulia Tymoshenko |publisher=File.liga.net |date=27 November 1960 |accessdate=11 October 2011}} (born 11 June 1960). The couple have a daughter – [[Eugenia Tymoshenko|Yevhenia (Eugenia) Tymoshenko]][https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/oct/16/yulia-tymoshenko-daughter-yevhenia-carr?INTCMP=SRCH Yulia Tymoshenko's daughter: 'My mother's trial was a trial of revenge'], ''[[The Guardian]]'' (16 October 2011)
[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/sep/23/eugenia-tymoshenko-fight-to-save-mother-yulia Eugenia Tymoshenko: the fight to save my mother Yulia], ''[[The Guardian]]'' (23 September 2012){{uk icon}} [http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2011/12/26/6867849/ Донька Тимошенко взяла мамине прізвище. Для політики?], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (16 December 2011) (born 20 February 1980) – a graduate of the [[London School of Economics]] (Bsc "Government", Msc "Russian and Post-Soviet Studies"). ===Personal life=== Tymoshenko and her husband rent a house in Kiev and own an apartment in Dnipro. Houses in Dnipro belong to their relatives.[http://www.unian.info/society/108197-tymoshenko-declares-her-incomes.html Tymoshenko declares her incomes], [[UNIAN]] (7 April 2008) Tymoshenko has declared she never used and will never use or move into a state-owned [[dacha|summer house]],[https://web.archive.org/web/20111009164610/http://www.tymoshenko.ua/en/article/c2nxnnv8 As President, Yulia Tymoshenko will not use state dachas], Official website of Yulia Tymoshenko (4 January 2010)[https://web.archive.org/web/20120314222109/http://www.tymoshenko.ua/en/article/mx56a7ss Yulia Tymoshenko has never used a government summer house], Official website of Yulia Tymoshenko (19 December 2009) in contrast with all former-Presidents and many high-ranking officials of Ukraine, who live in state-owned [[dachas]] in [[Koncha-Zaspa]].[https://web.archive.org/web/20100513032102/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/66006/ Ukrayinska Pravda exposes president's Mezhygirya deal], ''Kyiv Post'' (6 May 2009) According to Ukrainian media, Tymoshenko lives in an estate in Koncha-Zaspa, "rented from a friend". In March 2014, Tymoshenko opened the door of her house to public activists and guided them around.{{cite news|url= http://tabloid.pravda.com.ua/photos/5333f5829cc40/|script-title= uk:Тимошенко на підборах показала активістам свій маєток у Конча-Заспі|trans-title=Tymoshenko showed activists around her mansion in Koncha Zaspa in her high heels|language= uk|publisher= Tabloid.pravda.com.ua|date= 27 March 2014|accessdate= 26 July 2014}} In her spare time, before she was imprisoned, Tymoshenko ran on a [[treadmill]] for exercise and listened to the music of [[Andrea Bocelli]], [[Sarah Brightman]], [[Anna Netrebko]] and [[Alessandro Safina]]. ''[[Ukrayinska Pravda]]'' and [[Лівий берег]] are her favourite news sources. [http://tabloid.pravda.com.ua/person/4d4a92dc5f4cb/ Тимошенко у домогосподарки не піде, а у Facebook – обіцяє], [[Tablo ID]] (3 February 2011) {{qn|date=February 2016}} Tymoshenko stated that she watched the [[Tunisian Revolution]] and [[Egyptian Revolution of 2011]] "with joy and admiration". ==Cultural and political image== [[File:Timoshenko-bez-kosy.JPG|thumb|upright|left|Tymoshenko without her trademark hair [[braids]]]] Tymoshenko is a voluble public performer.[https://web.archive.org/web/20110128152034/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/58428/ Ukraine's Yanukovich shuns TV face-off with rival], ''Kyiv Post'' (1 February 2010) Her fiery rhetoric made her an icon of the [[Orange Revolution]] Tymoshenko's critics have suggested that, as an oligarch, she gained her fortune improperly. Some have speculated that her familiarity with the illegal conduct of business common in Ukraine uniquely qualifies her to combat corruption—if she is willing to do so. Her former business partner, former Ukrainian Prime Minister [[Pavlo Lazarenko]], was convicted in the United States on charges of [[money laundering]], [[corporate crime|corruption]] and fraud, the magnitude of which was in the billions of dollars.{{cite news|title=Former Ukraine PM is jailed in US|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/5287870.stm|publisher=BBC News |date=25 August 2006|accessdate=26 August 2006}} However, on 7 May 2004, Judge Martin Jenkins of the US District Court for the Northern District of California dismissed the allegations of Tymoshenko's involvement in Lazarenko's murky business.{{cite web|last=Kupchinsky |first=Roman |url=http://www.rferl.org/content/article/1052721.html |title=Many Charges Dropped Against Ukraine's Ex-Premier |publisher=Rferl.org |date=10 May 2004 |accessdate=28 December 2013}} Her transition from [[Ukrainian oligarch|oligarch]] to reformer was believed by many voters to be both genuine and effective.{{cite news|last=Levy|first=Clifford J.|title='The braid' is crowning glory for the Ukrainian politician Yulia Tymoshenko|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/10/07/world/europe/07iht-hair.4.7786675.html|accessdate=29 July 2012|date=7 October 2007|newspaper=The New York Times}} Discrepancies between her declared income and her seemingly luxurious lifestyle (mostly because of her designer outfits) have been pointed out in the Ukrainian tabloids.{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/70065/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100623011139/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/70065/|archivedate=23 June 2010|title=While leading lavish lifestyles, politicians declare almost pauper-like incomes, assets|publisher=Kyiv Post|date=17 June 2010}}{{uk icon}} [http://tabloid.pravda.com.ua/brand/4a391ace277c4/ Тимошенко і "Віттон" – Люксембурзький "мове тон"], [[Tablo ID]] (17 June 2009){{uk icon}} [http://tabloid.pravda.com.ua/brand/4922e4a28d23c/ Юлія Тимошенко і Катерина Ющенко вдарили по Chanel], Tablo ID (19 November 2008) When Tymoshenko joined the Yushchenko government, she did not speak Ukrainian. According to fellow Ukrainian politician [[Borys Tarasyuk]], in 2002 Tymoshenko "only spoke Russian even when I spoke to her in [[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]]", but since then she has made the transition to speaking only Ukrainian.{{cite book|author=Laada Bilaniuk|title=Contested Tongues: Language Politics and Cultural Correction in Ukraine|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gncrr5KrFvIC&pg=PA68|accessdate=30 January 2016|year=2005|publisher=Cornell University Press|isbn=0-8014-7279-2|pages=68–69}}{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/news/world/europe/articles/2010/01/13/orange_leaders_face_shutout_in_ukraine_election/|title=Orange Leaders Face Shutout in Ukraine Election|work=[[ABC News]]|date=13 January 2010|accessdate=29 January 2016}} During her second stint as prime-minister her ratings in opinion polls fell. In early 2008, in opinion polls for the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2009]], she stood at 30% but by late April 2009 that had shrunk to 15%See [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2010#Opinion polls]] for references and more information According to a poll carried out between 29 January and 5 February 2009 by the [[Kyiv International Institute of Sociology]], just over 43% of the Ukrainian voters believed Tymoshenko should leave her post, whereas just over 45% believed she should stay.{{cite news|url=http://www.unian.info/society/191796-poll-says-ukraines-president-should-step-down-now.html|title=Poll says Ukraine's president should step down now|work=UNIAN/RIA Novosti|date=17 February 2009|accessdate=29 January 2016}} According to an opinion poll carried out between 3 and 12 February 2009 by the "Sofia" Center for Social Studies, some 59.1% of those polled believed that the activities of (then) Prime Minister Yulia Tymoshenko were aimed at the defense of her own interests and that of her entourage, some 4.2% said her activities were aimed at the defense of interests of foreign states, and some 23.9% believed that Tymoshenko worked for the sake of national interests. 77.7% of the respondents were unsatisfied with the economic policy of the [[second Tymoshenko Government]]. Some 71.8% believed that this government was not able to lead the [[Ukrainian economy]] out of the [[2008–09 Ukrainian financial crisis]] or even change the situation in Ukraine to better; 18.1% of respondents did think that the government could do that.{{cite news|url=http://www.unian.info/politics/191826-majority-of-ukrainians-believe-tymoshenko-defends-her-own-interests.html|title=Majority of Ukrainians believe Tymoshenko defends her own interests|work=UNIAN|date=17 February 2009|accessdate=7 November 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/8403.html|title=Ukrainians have lost confidence in government's handling of crisis, says poll|agency=Interfax-Ukraine|date=17 February 2009|accessdate=7 November 2015}} Despite the neck-to-neck 2010 presidential race, many experts believed that Tymoshenko would win the vote due to her ability to "hike her popularity just before the voting day". JP Morgan Securities Inc. experts said that Tymoshenko's victory in presidential election would "bring stability in 2010, with budget consolidation, better terms of crediting and higher influx of capital. As a result, the economy will have better prospects of growing in the second half of 2010 and 2011".{{cite web|url=http://zik.ua/en/news/2009/10/31/202645|title=What's in store for Ukraine if Tymoshenko wins presidential election|publisher=Zik.ua|date=31 October 2009|accessdate=28 December 2013}} Tymoshenko has been ranked three times by ''Forbes'' magazine among the most powerful women in the world. During her first term in 2005, she was ranked third (behind [[Condoleezza Rice]] and [[Wu Yi (politician)|Wu Yi]]), in 2008 she was number 17{{cite news|title=The 100 Most Powerful Women|url=https://www.forbes.com/lists/2008/11/biz_powerwomen08_The-100-Most-Powerful-Women_Rank.html|work=Forbes|date=27 August 2008|accessdate=27 August 2008}} and in 2009 at number 47.{{cite news|title=The 100 Most Powerful Women – No.47 Yulia Tymoshenko|url=https://www.forbes.com/lists/2009/11/power-women-09_Yulia-Tymoshenko_PGEZ.html|work=Forbes|date=20 August 2009}} According to the Ukrainian magazine ''[[Focus (Ukrainian magazine)|Focus]]'', Tymoshenko placed first in an annual ranking of the most influential women in Ukraine in 2006–2010 (five years).{{cite news|url=http://tabloid.pravda.com.ua/focus/4ce52c33d597e/|script-title=uk:ТОП-100 найвпливовіших жінок: родички Кучми та Ющенка і "невмируща" Тимошенко|trans-title=Top 100 most influential women: relatives of Kuchma and Yushchenko and the "immortal" Tymoshenko|language=uk|publisher=Tabloid.pravda.com.ua|date=18 November 2010|accessdate=7 November 2015}}{{cite web|url=https://focus.ua/ratings/156273/|script-title=ru:100 самых влиятельных женщин Украины. Рейтинг Фокуса|trans-title=The 100 most influential women in Ukraine. Focus's rating|language=ru|publisher=Focus.ua|date=18 November 2010|accessdate=7 November 2015}} During the Orange Revolution, some Western media publications dubbed her the "[[Joan of Arc]] of the Revolution". In December 2011, Tymoshenko's party [[BYuT-Batkivschyna]] nominated her for the [[Nobel Peace Prize]].{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/119025|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111230093249/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/119025/|archivedate=30 December 2011|title=Korolevska: BYT nominating Tymoshenko for Nobel Peace Prize|work=Kyiv Post|date=15 December 2011}} Russian Prime Minister Vladimir Putin has stated (in November 2009) he found it comfortable to work with his (then) Ukrainian counterpart Yulia Tymoshenko and also praised her for strengthening Ukrainian sovereignty and building stable ties with Moscow{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/53261/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110217043924/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/53261/|archivedate=17 February 2011|title=Russia's Putin says comfortable with Ukraine's Tymoshenko|work=Kyiv Post|date=20 November 2009}} and called the [[second Tymoshenko Government]] "efficient and a force for stability".{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/53265/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091124072235/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/53265/|archivedate=24 November 2009|title=Putin gives Ukraine a break on gas deal|work=Kyiv Post|date=20 November 2009}} It has been suggested by [[Reuters]] that the [[Russian government]], after seeing her opposition to Viktor Yushchenko, supported her since late 2008, although Putin denied it. Former ally and President of Ukraine Victor Yushchenko stated in November 2009, "I am sure that every week spent by Yulia Tymoshenko in the post of Prime Minister leads the country to a catastrophe. Because of Yulia Tymoshenko, it is a crisis, a crisis in everything".{{cite news|url=http://www.unian.info/politics/292921-tymoshenkos-activity-at-post-of-prime-minister-is-reason-of-crises-in-ukraine-yushchenko.html|title=Tymoshenko's activity at post of Prime Minister is reason of crises in Ukraine – Yushchenko|work=UNIAN|date=24 November 2009|accessdate=7 November 2015}} Yushchenko has repeatedly accused his former ally turned rival Tymoshenko of acting in the interests of Russia, although she firmly denied the allegations. On 31 May 2010, Yushchenko stated that Tymoshenko was his "worst mistake", "The most serious mistake was to give the power to her twice".[https://web.archive.org/web/20100604055659/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/68117 Yushchenko told about his 'worst mistake'], ''Kyiv Post'' (31 May 2010) Expert in [[Ukrainian politics]] Dr. [[Taras Kuzio]] believes that he has always prioritized personal revenge against Tymoshenko over Ukraine's national interests.{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/news/opinion/op_ed/detail/116989/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111116025514/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/opinion/op_ed/detail/116989/|archivedate=16 November 2011|title=Yushchenko's hand in the imprisonment of Yulia Tymoshenko|work=Kyiv Post|date=17 November 2011}} In her turn, Tymoshenko has blamed President Viktor Yushchenko for obstructing the government-proposed anti-crisis measures and efforts to form a broad coalition to battle the crisis. "The president is using flashy words today to deprive the nation, first of all its government, of the opportunity to counter the crisis, and to leave the nation without a government it logically needs" she said. "Viktor Yushchenko has no right to any criticism. He is the incumbent president. He only has the right to work and to serve Ukraine. He will have the right to criticize when he joins the opposition. Now he must work and answer for his moves".{{cite web|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/tymoshenko-blames-yushchenko-for-obstructing-gover-43070.html|title=Tymoshenko blames Yushchenko for obstructing government's fight against crisis|publisher=Kyivpost.com|date=9 June 2009|accessdate=28 December 2013}} {{Quote box|width=40%|align=right|quote= Yushchenko is being dishonest—which shouldn't surprise us—but he is also being self-serving when he says that Yanukovych and Tymoshenko "are cut from the same cloth." For one thing, even Tymoshenko's most ardent detractors realize that, if she were president, Ukraine would not be sliding toward a 20-year dictatorship. For another, if anyone is cut from the same cloth as Yanukovych, it's Viktor Yushchenko, who's shown a remarkable willingness to seek rapprochement with him and the Regionnaires since 2005. Yushchenko should be ashamed. Worse, Yushchenko should be on meds. A perfectly reasonable argument for EU engagement with Ukraine became, in the manner of all of Yushchenko's speeches in the last years of his presidency, a rant against Tymoshenko and thereby self-destructed. I had once suggested that Yushchenko probably couldn't forgive himself for being too weak to stand up to the powerful Tymoshenko. His feelings of impotence are obviously still going strong. |source=Yanukovych's Galleon and Yushchenko's Obsession, Alexander Motyl, The World Affairs Journal, 27 August 2012}} Former Ukrainian Minister of Finance of Ukraine [[Viktor Pynzenyk]] has called Tymoshenko's decisions "normally guided by 'adventurous populism'", which she saw as a tool to "consolidate power in her own hands" and believed Tymoshenko should have "taken advantage of the opportunity presented by the [[2008–2009 Ukrainian financial crisis]] to reform".{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/91996/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101204135319/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/91996/|archivedate=4 December 2010|title=Pynzenyk, ex-finance minister, calls Tymoshenko "destructive force"|work=Kyiv Post|date=3 December 2010}} [[Party of Regions]] Deputy Head [[Borys Kolesnykov]] stated on 11 February 2010, "Tymoshenko was the most effective politician during the entire period of Ukraine's recent history".{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/59285/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100213164447/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/59285/|archivedate=13 February 2010|title=Regions Party calls Tymoshenko most effective opposition figure in Ukraine|work=Kyiv Post|date=11 February 2010}} Former European High Representative for Common Foreign and Security Policy [[Javier Solana]] has called Tymoshenko "a patriot regardless of the position in which you have found yourself".{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/62960/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110605065144/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/62960/|archivedate=5 June 2011|title=Solana happy with Tymoshenko's constructive mood in opposition|work=Kyiv Post|date=1 April 2010}} President Viktor Yanukovych stated about Tymoshenko on 13 May 2010, "She likes to create a sensation.
